AryehGregor, has there been any discussion about what the Wikitext markup will look like for microdata? Will there be any attempt to provide even more shortcuts than Microdata alone provides?

Lachy, it's certainly no more complicated than, say, style="", and we allow raw input of that (well, lightly filtered).  We'd just allow it in wikitext.  In practice, it would probably be hidden behind templates.
At least IMO.
ok
foolip, I'm not getting a straight answer in #wikimedia-commons, but it looks like they're hidden because they're mostly useless for navigation.
so, I haven't followed the whole wikimedia thread, but does there seem to be consensus growing around the idea of using microdata?

ok

how does the rdfa support work? Does that just requrie authors to write RDFa attributes into the wikitext?
Tim Starling is the one who will make the final decision if there's disagreement, but I don't think he has a real opinion.
Yeah, same deal, they have to write the raw RDFa.  But this will only be a few elite template editors actually doing the authoring.
Probably.
Does that mean it would be easy to edit all the templates to fix them if the spec changes?
Similarly, you rarely find much raw style="" in Wikipedia articles' wikitext.

perhaps one way of helping to get this to go into your favour is to show that since microdata maps easily to RDFa, converting microdata in wikitext to RDFa is easy, and thus making it output RDFa in the generated HTML can be done. That would at least reduce the sense of lock-in being created by committing to one early on.
That's true, we could probably do that.  I'll wait for other devs to comment first, though.
If everyone agrees with me, not much point in doing the work.
What I was thinking of doing is trying to get some POC RDF output, in a separate data stream, to discourage people from thinking about using RDFa/microdata for "Augustus is an emperor" type info.
yeah. I don't think that ability will matter in practice. Just thought it was a way to sway those who are sitting on the fence
It goes both ways, though.
is POC = Proof Of Concept?
Yeah.
Hixie, data URIs could be used instead of doc="". Though, doc does help to reduce the amount of required boilerplate.
Lachy, the consensus in #mediawiki seems to be "avoid flamewars by disabling it for now".
Unsurprisingly.
I said that in the earlier discussion, having both specs on standards tracks will make authors reluctant to use either.

Hixie, that technique would also allow easy server-side detection by checking the Accept header when generating the page. If Accept contains text/html-sandboxed, output data URI. Otherwise, output nothing or HTTP URI to server side alternative.
Lachy: I don't think adding another 20 bytes to every web request in the entire world is a good idea, for a feature approximately nobody will use

Sorry, commenting on Dashiva's link.
I thought that hsivonen said the hidden attribute was removing things from the DOM, and AryehGregor that user agents should ignore the content of this part. I guess I have to read the thread again.
UAs should indeed ignore it when rendering.  If hsivonen said it was removing things from the DOM, he's either mistaken or misspoke.
http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/editing.html#the-hidden-attribute
The spec makes it pretty clear that it's just a rendering issue.
more chances that I misinterpret him, which makes my questions, my comments out of scope.
The important bit is that it applies to *all* possible user interaction modes, so it's not just a visual hiding.

>Elements in a section hidden by the hidden attribute are still active, e.g. scripts and form controls in such sections still execute and submit respectively. Only their presentation to the user changes.
Not remove it from the DOM, but treat that subtree as if it wasn't there
:) my questions are moot then!
*sighs* about himself
Dashiva: I think that's still a very unclear way of stating it.  The subtree is certainly still there for, say, scripts.
It's merely a matter of getting the equivalent of display:none for all interaction mediums.
(though display:none is already forced to be equivalent to @hidden, since it is used for this purpose so often.)
At least, it seems there is misunderstanding by people. Hmmm I wonder what would be a better way to reformulate it
considers questioning whether the flaws in localStorage and autobuffer would have been noticed if there had been no implementations, decides not to bother

I think it's valid to point out, jgraham.  Before implementation only browser authors and spec readers can find problems.  After implementation early-adopter users can start looking for problems, and they're actually putting it to use rather than just imagining what might theoretically be a problem.
They're the beta testers for specs.  I don't think there's a single sane developer alive who thinks that beta testers are not an absolute requirement for good software.
You could make an analogy to open source and closed source
The more people playing with a feature, the better it gets tested
Enough eyes, shallow bugs, etc.
Well, enough hands :)
Interaction medium racist!  Eyes are just hands for the visual!
All kinds of things seem reasonable in theory, but when you try to use it there's this nasty reality thing getting in the way
Oh I have no doubt it is a valid thing to point out. I'm just not convinced there is any point to increasing the volume of email to point out something that is basically unchangable anyway
somehow more than hidden attribute, it has a notion of "camouflage", "undercover", "conceal" with the benefit of less spelling mistake because of the double d
Well, Boris is making a mistake in lamenting localStorage's implementation.  We wouldn't have known it was a problem before implementation.
I don't care about correcting some of the more trollish people, but we should make sure that the browser authors are on the right page.  ^_^
Oh OK then. But it is your own fault that I am filling up your inbox :)
It would probably be better to point it out now, rather than have someone else use it as a flawed argument later
jgraham: One more email won't matter to the torrent.
Dashiva: That probably won't stop someone, but still.  I'd rather that *Boris* not end up using it as a flawed argument later.
TabAtkins: experimental implementation vs mainstream implementation. An alpha release could be used to test things, but should not go into the mainstream until it is really tested.
"Really tested", though, doesn't really happen until you get a lot of users.  That's the difference between an alpha and a beta.
Also, the web doesn't really have a distinction between alpha, beta, and public.  The best you can do is keep it in nightlies and not release it to the public build.
Spec writers and early adopters are not very representative of the average user either

karlcow: The @autobuffer thing is a really good example. Lots of people in specs land knew exactly how that attribute worked and could have suggested the change at any time if they had realised the design was flawed. But it was not until someone tried to use it in production that the flaw became obvious
And I doubt that person would ever have read the spec if it couldn't be used
The way I tend to talk about "hidden" is to discuss it in terms of interface state.
webben: yes for me, it is like a mask.
effectively "hidden" demarks subtrees that are not presented in the current interface state.
I'm not sure what a mask would be in this context.
I find it easier to just say "What display:none does for visual browsers, @hidden does for all possible browsers, including screen-readers and such."
take a cardboard, cut a hole (then the mask), move the cardboard along the page, you have access to some part of the text.
transparent :)
TabAtkins: That's problematic, because display:none applies to multiple media and will typically, but not hide content from popular screen readers too.
*but not always,
otoh the fact that people are already using display: none; for this does suggest that they will use "hidden" vaguely correctly at least some of the time.
That's technically true, but the average author only pays attention to visual media, and thus naturally only thinks about display:none hiding things visually.
Yeah, I more mean, explaining it that way is likely to increase misuse of display: none; among those who think it only affects sighted users.
Which leads to problems when they try to visually hide something with display:none, but ATs have realized that to present the web compatibly they need to ignore display:none content as well.
Ah, gotcha.  Well, screen-readers use media=screen anyway.
I know. But that doesn't help.
i.e. if authors get the impression: use display: none; to hide things visually; and hidden to remove things from current interface state
then things they mean to show to AT but not to sighted users will probably get hidden from both.
That's happening right now, though, for any author that doesn't realize that ATs pay attention to display:none.
Oh absolutely.
I'm just saying explaining hidden with your example language exacerbates that situation.
Ok, granted.  But it's still simpler than talking about interface states.  ^_^
if anyone can come up with simpler language that is as precise, I'd prefer to adopt it.
(I've had some success managing to explain the principal that the DOM contains one interface state to people in IRC, so it's not utterly useless as language.)
Just use my language with a parenthetical after it describing the actual situation with display:none on the ground.
*principle
maybe what this situation needs is a flowchart ;)
Alternately, use the relatively well-known practice of position:absolute;left:-9001px;, which *is* a purely visual matter so far.
If the user knows about @media: GOTO A

foolip: I think ALTERNATE-STYLESHEET is uppercase so that it can't ever conflict with an actual rel value
i.e. you can't generate it with rel="ALTERNATE-STYLESHEET" (because values get lowercased)
so it uniquely identifies the fact that there's both "alternate" and "stylesheet" tokens
